raw_text: It has been pointed outin (Zens and Ney, 2003) that the ITG constraints can be characterized as follows: a re ordering violates the ITG constraints if and only if it contains (3, 1, 4, 2) or (2, 4, 1, 3) as a subsequence
clean_text: It has been pointed out in (Zens and Ney, 2003) that the ITG constraints can be characterized as follows: a reordering violates the ITG constraints if and only if it contains (3, 1, 4, 2) or (2, 4, 1, 3) as a subsequence.

raw_text: German (4.2%) or Portuguese? Spanish (8.1%), which seems to have motivated research on extensions of ITGs (Zens and Ney, 2003)

Zens and Ney (2003) used GIZA++ to word-align the Verbmobil task (English and German) and the Canadian Hansards task (English and French) and tested the coverage of ITGs and xITGs ,i.e. the ratio of the number of alignment configurations that could be induced by the theories and the sentences in the two tasks
clean_text: Zens and Ney (2003) used GIZA++ to word-align the Verbmobil task (English and German) and the Canadian Hansards task (English and French) and tested the coverage of ITGs and xITGs, i.e. the ratio of the number of alignment configurations that could be induced by the theories and the sentences in the two tasks.

raw_text: ITG imposes constraints on which alignments are possible, and these constraints have been shown to be a good match for real bi text data (Zens and Ney, 2003)
clean_text: ITG imposes constraints on which alignments are possible, and these constraints have been shown to be a good match for real bi text data (Zens and Ney, 2003).

raw_text: For a comparison and a more detailed discussion of the two approaches see (Zens and Ney, 2003) .A different approach to allow for a limited reordering is to reorder the input sentence such that the source and the target sentences have similar word order and then proceed to monotonically decode the reordered source sentence. Monotone decoding translates words in the same order they appear in the source language
clean_text: For a comparison and a more detailed discussion of the two approaches see (Zens and Ney, 2003).

citing_paper_authors: Taro, Watanabe | Hajime, Tsukada | Hideki, Isozaki
raw_text: Such reordering was realized either by an additional constraint for decoding, such as window constraints, IBM constraints or ITG-constraints (Zens and Ney,2003), or by lexicalized reordering feature functions (Tillman, 2004)
clean_text: Such reordering was realized either by an additional constraint for decoding, such as window constraints, IBM constraints or ITG-constraints (Zens and Ney,2003), or by lexicalized reordering feature functions (Tillman, 2004).

raw_text: Zens and Ney (2003) found that the constraints of ITG were a better match to the decoding task than the heuristics used in the IBM decoder of Berger et al (1996)
clean_text: Zens and Ney (2003) found that the constraints of ITG were a better match to the decoding task than the heuristics used in the IBM decoder of Berger et al (1996).

raw_text: The ITG we apply in our experiments has more structural labels than the primitive bracketing grammar: it has a start symbol S, a single preterminal C, and two inter me diate nonterminals A and B used to ensure that only one parse can generate any given word-level alignment, as discussed by Wu (1997) and Zens and Ney (2003)
clean_text: The ITG we apply in our experiments has more structural labels than the primitive bracketing grammar: it has a start symbol S, a single preterminal C, and two intermediate nonterminals A and B used to ensure that only one parse can generate any given word-level alignment, as discussed by Wu (1997) and Zens and Ney (2003).

raw_text: Some of the properties of these alignments are studied in (Zens and Ney, 2003)
clean_text: Some of the properties of these alignments are studied in (Zens and Ney, 2003).

clean_text: A comparison of both methods can be found in Zens and Ney (2003).

raw_text: A typical value of m is 4 (Zens and Ney, 2003), and we write IBM constraints with m= 4 as IBM (4)
clean_text: A typical value of m is 4 (Zens and Ney, 2003), and we write IBM constraints with m= 4 as IBM (4).

raw_text: Zens and Ney (2003) [3] show that ITG constraints yield significantly better alignment coverage than the constraints used in IBM statistical machine translation models on both German-English (Verbmobil corpus) and French-English (Canadian Hansards corpus)
clean_text: Zens and Ney (2003) [3] show that ITG constraints yield significantly better alignment coverage than the constraints used in IBM statistical machine translation models on both German-English (Verbmobil corpus) and French-English (Canadian Hansards corpus).
